data.title: The coffee house inside the Little Sparrow is incredible!
data.text:
Different coffees debut and are featured all the time here for a beyond wonderful experience every visit.
The coffee house will soon be moving to it's own location... at the clock tower.
Little Sparrow is great, but the coffee house has me going back more often.

data.title: Little restaurant with a big personality.
data.text: Love this little jewel.  A great addition to the area's fine dining experience.  The dinner menu is quite varied and each dish is extremely well prepared.  The service is friendly and helpful and the atmosphere is bistro like.  High Five to the Little Sparrow.

data.title: Missed the mark.
data.text: I hate to say bad things about restaurants, I love food and foodies, and I get the feeling the folks at Little Sparrow are that kind.  It was a Thursday (tonight),the place has a cool atmosphere, had a very nice waitress, a nice bartender, but service was really slow, about 20 minutes to get a water on the table.  There was very little urgency to serve.  Ordered a sea bass and octopus. Both fairly flavorful and unique, well prepared, octopus was tender, neither were very memorable though.  A big problem however, was the dishes were swimming in sauce. No rice or potato or bread to soak up the sauce, just sauce.  As you have read, the portions are made for a little sparrow so that combined with no carb left me and my mom hungry, disappointed and much lighter in the wallet. Also, I love cocktails but there were like 4 drinks with a similar honey lemon ginger theme... So kind of a strangely lopsided drink menu. The drink also, just ok. I had asked for some bread and the waitress said sure but it took so long, we ended up leaving before they brought the bread.  I can only imagine on a weekend how long it might tske to get served.  For my hard earned $, I recommend going elsewhere, unless they get the drift and start feeding their customers and stepping up the service.

data.title: Small portions, lacking flavor and presentation, the 1/2 fried chicken has everybody talking
data.text:
We visited Little Sparrow with a party of 5, and were advised that the menu was all new, sounded good.  
We were also told that each plate was intended to be shared "family style", including the appetizers, that would be served as they came out of the kitchen.  No problem, I was envisioning some sort of tapas style... except that each of the appetizers turned out to be quite difficult to share: the shrimp toast (2 pieces of toast smashed together with a broken egg on top, how do you share that?); the bone marrow (a bone cut in 2 with some excellent marrow in marmalade to scrape out, how do you share that as well?), Brussels sprouts (barely enough to share with 2 people), chicken and dumplings (very small dish, and the dumplings resembling gnocchi just did not have much flavor).  
As an entrée, we ordered the fried chicken: basically a 1/2 chicken served by itself on top of a wooden board, nut much style there.  Worse part, when we cut it, it started bleeding... after getting the attention of the wait staff, we were told that the chicken itself had been slow cooked for hours in a special process, and then deep fried, so it couldn't possibly be undercooked, although they admitted several other customers had been complaining.  We accepted the explanation, and half of the table went ahead eating it.  The meat tasted bland overall, except for a hint of sweetness.  What wasn't sweet was the price tab - $25 or 30 for a bare bone half chicken.  
Over $200 overall for a table of 5 with mostly appetizers, including 1 glass of wine and beer each.  
Will not repeat.

data.title: Not for the birds
data.text: My wife and I met up with another couple, friends of ours, for a nice night out. Food and service were great. The highlight though was the Gin Gin Mule cocktail. Had to have a second!

data.title: One of THE places to go in Santa Ana
data.text: We were taken here by a friend for lunch and found it to be a charming and delicious little place. Warm and inviting with a friendly staff. Some interesting seating on couches and over stuffed chairs. We had the lamb bowl, burrata, and burger and fries. All were terrific and tasty and nicely presented.

data.title: Small portions
data.text:
I have been wanting to try the Little Sparrow for a long time, but the reviews were a mix. When I saw a 30% off for LS on Black Board Eats I was surprised, because I don’t think they ever offered a deal in OC before. Still, I was not sure if it was worth a try, but since the options in OC are not that great, finally gave in and tried the Little Sparrow.
The setup of the place was the most bizarre of any restaurant I have ever been to. There is a very large coffee house in the front and a much smaller restaurant in the back. That is not the bizarre part though. Their kitchen is in the middle of the coffee house and the restaurant, but their pantries were in two different rooms facing the dining room. As we were sitting waiting for our food to arrive, I saw a parade of kitchen staff going back and forth to these rooms and walking away with all kind of produce. It was just unbelievable. Who came up with this insane setup? Service was OK. Our hostess/waitress was not well informed about the menu and made a mistake with our bill.
We had:
Chickpea Masala pomegranate, Yogurt
It sounded better than it tasted. The masala spice was there, but a little bit of salt would have done wonders for this dish. If you put yogurt and pomegranate as part of the ingredients, don’t skimp on it specially if you are charging $12 for it.

Lamb Merguez Couscous Bowl Harissa, Tzatziki
I encouraged my husband to try this dish and when we asked our waitress how gamey the lamb was, she responded it is gamey. Guess what? It was not gamey at all. He seemed to enjoy his dish. I took a little bite of the meatball and it was flavorful. The pita crisp looked a little greasy though.

Marinated Hanger Steak Salad Creamy Pepita Dressing, Tortilla Strips
My steak was in a desperate need of seasoning which was a shame considering the good quality of the beef. The salty tortilla strips helped to balance the dish. The dressing on the other hand was a little too spicy.

When we got the bill we were charged for a hanger steak dinner rather than the salad. I felt the value was not there considering the setup and lack of seasoning and I am glad we didn’t pay the full price. Also after our chickpea starter it took a long time for the rest of the food to arrive considering they were not even busy.

You can see the pictures at:
travel4foodnart

data.title: Great Find
data.text:
Beautiful little Restaurant/CoffeeHouse/Bar
Heard about it from someone and decided to go for lunch and so happy we did.  Great service and a really cool  interior.  It's doesn't seat many but that to me, is part of the charm!  All food is made fresh and from local sources. There were three of us and we had the hamburger...one of the best and most flavorful I've had in a long time!, the Shrimp Po'Boy...delicious! and the Lamb dish, very good!

data.title: Worth A Trip
data.text: Wonderful dinner starting with a craft cocktail. Food is multi-layered and flavorful. Menu is eclectic in a good way with a variety of unusual options. Had oysters, bone marrow and hanger streak.

data.title: Small Plates. Best New Restaurant in OC in 2014. Too Many of the Dishes Were Ordinary for Me to Love It
data.text: While we like small plates, we do tend to over-order... and we did. But the bigger dishes - the fried chicken, the beet salad, the faux chopped liver -- while being very good, just weren't very special. Craft beers and good drinks.

data.title: OMG!! This place is an hidden jem
data.text: Little Sparrow never disappoints, top quality foods plus super friendly service!! This small bistro type cafe reminds me cafes in Paris, perfect for an intimate date night,

data.title: What Happened?
data.text: We have been to Little Sparrow twice before and had an impressive meal. However, last Saturday, August 8, I persuaded my friend to go with me to Little Sparrow for an early dinner. We ordered the soft shell crab, the Japanese chicken (don't remember the name), and the beef to share. Typically, at fine dining restaurants, deep fried dishes are balanced with a light sauce and  some type of micro raw vegetable side for color, contrast, and complexity. The deep fried crab was covered with a heavy batter and served with a cream sauce. When the chicken came to our table, my friend said it looked like chicken nougats from a fast food restaurant. It came to our table with fried nougats piled up, nothing else. I couldn't believe it. The beef was okay. I could have made it better at home. The wine and cocktail was very good. But I felt cheated when I got the $90.00 bill. What happened to Little Sparrow?

data.title: Right up there
data.text: Really enjoyed it. I'm from Cape Cod  (where we used to be able to pick a peck of mussels monthly) and rarely order mussels on the west coast.  They were excellent.  Entire meal was good--from craft cocktails to dessert. Service was excellent, too.

data.title: Nice neighborhood gem
data.text: My wife and I decided to try out this restaurant since we read about it in many magazines as one of the best new restaurants.  We were very happy with the food and the price is reasonable.  The decor however needs some improvement and it can be very noisy due to the acoustic effect of the set up.  We ordered the mussels with Thai sauce and it was delicious.  The sauce has enough heat with a Thai flavor and the mussels from PEI were plump and juicy.  We also liked the quail as entree.  It was well seasoned and came with haricot vert and brown rice.

data.title: Fabulous food, good portion sizes
data.text:
This is a small cafe with maybe 25 seats in the dining room, and a bar in the back. Appetizers from $5-13, Entrees in the $15-30 range. They were thoughtful and well composed, and they were not "pricey" at all, unless you are used to eating at Chipotle. 

The salad was burrata cheese, pomegranate, and squash was particularly well composed, a good mixture of texture and flavor. The shrimp appetizer w/  carrot used real, honest to good heads attached prawns. They were delicious. The savory Japanese popcorn was salty and had a little tang to it. The chef sent a pepper stuffed with God and potatoes on top of some favs beans. While I wasn't crazy about the fish filling, the beans were incredible: really! Just a matter of personal taste, perhaps I just don't like cod. My strawberry cobbler with ice cream was to die for ($9). Everything was well executed. I will be back!

data.title: Loud, Pricey and Average Food
data.text:
Little Sparrow has been on my "to try" list quite awhile.  I happened to see the restaurant, owners and staff on Best New Restaurant with Tom Colicchio, so figured it was time to try this little spot in an upcoming area of Santa Ana, California.

We walked in through the bar and were seated right away because we had a reservation.  The bar is cool and inviting, the dining room is nice, but small.  Our server came over quickly and offered suggestions for drinks.  We decided to split a bottle of wine as there were 4 of us.  She brought the wine and poured and we enjoyed it while going over the menu.  The menu has some very interesting dishes.  Each couple ordered a salad to split and were very happy with the salads and they were large enough to split.

We ordered the Kabocha Squash Salad.  Which was frisee lettuce, with fresh burrata cheese, roasted squash and pomegranate seeds with a vinaigrette dressing.  Our friends ordered the Escarole Salad and seemed happy with it.

We ordered our entree's and waited a very reasonable time for them to come out of the kitchen.  The duck breast a top the parsnip risotto was very good, the duck was cooked perfectly.  My Beet, Ricotta Gnocchi was good, but very one note.  The ricotta was a small dollop on top, somewhat disappointing.  The Cod dish was seasoned well, but was lukewarm from the kitchen and the pasta dish was described as good.

I found that some of the problems they had on Best New Restaurant with dishes being inconsistent, still are running a bit true.  

The service was okay, nothing fantastic for a restaurant wanting to be upscale.  I will tell you that it didn't leave a lasting impression, and doubt we will go back.  The restaurant is very loud, and it is hard to have a conversation when you are with someone special or friends.

When I am hearing a lot of buzz about a new restaurant, it is featured on a tv show and the writer for our local restaurant puts it in his top 75 list, I have high expectations.  I really don't feel it is one of the best new restaurants in the OC.

Our salads ran anywhere from $11 to $13 dollars, the least expensive bottle of wine was $45 and the entree's will set you back anywhere from the low $20's to high $30's, which is average for a higher end restaurant.

The restaurant is located in downtown Santa Ana in a new upcoming area with some great restaurants.  There is paid parking in a parking garage behind the restaurant, street parking will be hard to find.  I recommend reservations.

data.title: Satisfactory
data.text: Average at best: grilled shrimp appetizer=2 not charred enough pieces; squash and burrata salad had 4 apricot-sized scrawny squash slices albeit with tasty burrata; salmon needed more excitement. Cornmeal strawberry dessert was fresh and nice but doesn't compensate for otherwise underwhelming meal.

data.title: Bad brunch
data.text: I watch a lot of TV, especially restaurant and cooking competitions so when I saw Little Sparrow in competition for best new restaurant, I was in. I went there for Sunday brunch and while the place is quaint with a nice looking bar area, I knew I was in trouble when it took longer than expected to place a drink order. They have bottomless mimosas for a reasonable price which was fine, but I also ordered French press coffee. The waitress made it seem like I didn't know what I was ordering and advised that it was a lot of coffee and I may be better off ordering a cappuccino. I should have listened to her, but instead I asked her to please bring two cups and if needed, I would share my coffee with my guest. Well, she returned with the mimosas, but no coffee. We ordered our meals and waited and waited. The restaurant was not full, so I was not sure why it took so long for French toast that was hard to chew and some cold hash browns. We were half way through the mediocre meal when I finally received my coffee. After pouring it, I brought the cup to my lips and I smelled a peculiar aroma. It smelled like someone had placed vegetable juice in my cup, poured it out, but didn't rinse it out and then poured my coffee in it. I took a sniff from the press and determined the smell was coming from the coffee and not the cup. The coffee tasted terrible. French press should taste strongly of coffee, but this was weak. I would have asked for something else, but no one came to check on us and our cold food and disgusting coffee. The check was also received long after we had finished and was set down without the usual, "how was everything?" I suspect it was because she could already tell by our faces. I will give the restaurant one more chance because I heard they have a killer pork chop, but I do not recommend this place to start your beautiful Sunday in So Cal.

data.title: good food but not a good experience.
data.text:
This place is rated as one of the best new restaurants in Orange County, but a great restaurant experience is more than good food. Our service was slow and seating was very uncomfortable. Trying to maximize success means cramming as many patrons as possible into a small space using really uncomfortable seating and tables 

The food was good but we were glad to leave. This is not a place to linger with friends for dinner, drinks and conversation. Chairs too small and too high for the small tables.

data.title: WOW, just wow
data.text:
We had reservations and were seated promptly.  The food served timely, hot food was hot and the cold food was cold and the drinks were perfect!  We split an appetizer which was excellent, the entrees were the Special Pork Chop and Braised Short Ribs, both excellent.  And for dessert we each had the Huckleberry Cornmeal Cobbler, it was not quite what we expected but it was still very good.  The drinks, what can you say but wow!  All of this plus an outstanding server! 

"If" there was any negative, for $150 I would like to see, or hear the ocean.
